Package gw.transaction

  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    AbstractBundleTransactionCallback  
    BundleTransactionCallback
    Defines a block of code that can be registered with a bundle to run during the database transaction used when the bundle is committed. Bundle.commit does the following: A connection is reserved from the connection pool A bundle version is pushed so we can rollback to the existing state if something fails. The pre-update rules are called if not overridden (message transport, message reply, non strict RPCE webservices) Internal bean callbacks beforeRemove, beforeInsert, and then beforeUpdate on the deleted, new and updated beans. (Internal only) Validation is executed if not overridden (message transport, message reply, non strict RPCE webservices). NOTE: before this is called we first go to the DB and try to refresh all beans that have not been edited. This is to ensure validate is getting the newest version of the beans. Editable and versionable field values, i.e. update/create time and user, are set + we increment the version number on the bean. All IDs on the new beans are set; giving new beans ids and fixing all FK references. Events created for bean changes if not overridden (message transport, message reply, non strict RPCE webservices) Call Event Fired rulesets for the events in the bundle. For each messaging destination that listens for those events, the application calls the Event Fired ruleset for each event. The rules may create messages that will be added to the current bundle. See the Integration Guide for details. Changed beans are written to the DB connection The internal bundle state is updated to reflect the write The connection is committed to the DB The global cache is updated. The update causes messages to be sent to other nodes in the cluster causing them to evict the beans that were updated or deleted. They will then be lazily re-read from the DB on those machines Beans in this cache are "updated" to reflect the new bean(s) state. We do not re-read from the DB on the node the beans were changed on. WARNING: Using the callback methods could lead to data corruption (unvalidated data) and other bad things (no preupdate rules run). The above order is the happy path. If the commit fails, some of the callback methods will have been called and afterCommit will be called, but others may not have been. So the beans, although not written to the database, may have changes. Some beans (like Documents) have different rollback actions that need to be allowed for in your afterCommit on failure method. WARNING: These callbacks are added to the bundle after each attempt to commit this list will be cleared. See afterCommit. adding a callback multiple times will cause the callback to be called multiple times, even if it is the same instance. they are called in the order added. WARNING: Do not use BundleTransactionCallback with Archiving or Importing without explicit approval. These use a different commit path. Use at your own risk.
    Transaction
    Helper class used to get the current transaction bundle or to start a new bundle transaction.
    Transaction.BlockRunnable
